posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14500835
Actual story:
Around 625 Muhammad proposed to Zaynab that she marry his adopted son, Zayd ibn Harithah. Zayd had been born into the Kalb tribe but as a child he had been kidnapped by slave-traders. He had been sold to a nephew of Khadija bint Khuwaylid, who in her turn had given him as a wedding present to her husband Muhammad. After some years, Muhammad had manumitted Zayd and had adopted him as his son.
Zaynab, supported by her brother Abdullah, at first refused the proposal on the grounds that, "I am the widow of a Quraysh." She presumably meant that Zaynab's social status was too high to allow her to marry an ex-slave. It has been asserted that these social differences were precisely the reason why Muhammad wanted to arrange the marriage:
"The Prophet was well aware that it is a person’s standing in the eyes of Allah that is important, rather than his or her status in the eyes of the people... their marriage would demonstrate that it was not who their ancestors were, but rather their standing in the sight of Allah, that mattered."
It has also been suggested that he wanted to establish the legitimacy and right to equal treatment of the adopted. By contrast, Montgomery Watt points out that Zayd was high in Muhammad's esteem.
"She can hardly have thought that he was not good enough. She was an ambitious woman, however, and may already have hoped to marry Muhammad; or she may have wanted to marry someone with whom Muhammad did not want his family to be so closely allied."
When Muhammad announced a new verse of the Qur'an:
It is not for a believing man or a believing woman, when Allah and His Messenger have decided a matter, that they should [thereafter] have any choice about their affair. And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly strayed into clear error,
Zaynab acquiesced and married Zayd. Muhammad personally paid the dower of 160 dirhams in cash, a cloak and veil, a coat of armour, 50 mudd of grain and 10 mudd of dates.

Aristotle's theology placed the Gods as the Prime Movers (plural, there's more than one) that move the planets in the sky. Fillmore was hardly motivated to run for a second term and the only reasons he was denied it in the first place is because he put the interests of the country over petty sectionalism, which alienated Northern Whigs, even if it delayed the Civil War or secession for a decade and the Whigs' autistic obsession with running generals. Sol Invictus (Classical Latin: [s̠ɔːl inˈwik.t̪us̠], "Unconquered Sun"), sometimes simply known as Helios, was long considered to be the official sun god of the later Roman Empire. In recent years, however, the scholarly community has become divided on Sol between traditionalists and a growing group of revisionists.[2]

In the traditional view, Sol Invictus was the second of two entirely different sun gods in Rome. The first of these, Sol Indiges, or Sol, was an early Roman deity of minor importance whose cult had petered out by the first century AD. Sol Invictus, on the other hand, was a Syrian sun god whose cult was first promoted in Rome under Elagabalus, without success. Some fifty years later, on 25 December AD 274, the Roman emperor Aurelian established the cult of Sol Invictus as an official religion, alongside the traditional Roman cults.[3][4]

The concept of Hellenistic religion as the late form of Ancient Greek religion covers any of the various systems of beliefs and practices of the people who lived under the influence of ancient Greek culture during the Hellenistic period and the Roman Empire (c. 300 BCE to 300 CE). There was much continuity in Hellenistic religion: people continued to worship the Greek gods and to practice the same rites as in Classical Greece.

Change came from the addition of new religions from other countries, including the Egyptian deities Isis and Serapis, and the Syrian gods Atargatis and Hadad, which provided a new outlet for people seeking fulfillment in both the present life and the afterlife. The worship of deified Hellenistic rulers also became a feature of this period, most notably in Egypt, where the Ptolemies adapted earlier Egyptian practices and Greek hero-cults and established themselves as Pharaohs within the new syncretic Ptolemaic cult of Alexander the Great. Elsewhere, rulers might receive divine status without achieving the full status of a god.

I unapologetically believe my personal beliefs are the absolute truth. How could I not? If I didn't, I'd have no right to call them my beliefs.
I know you believe differently from me. That's fine. You're wrong. You may protest that I have no authority to declare the truth for others, only myself. That's fine. That's no excuse to expect me to let you declare the truth for me either. posts.name: Anonymous

>>14498382
Yes, it refers to the Hellenic civilization as a whole. But Orthodoxy is necessarily international. This is why modern Greeks who are overtly traditional and religious call themselves "Romioi" (i.e. "Eastern Romans") instead of just Greeks. In other words, a "proper" Orthodox Greek must essentially renounce his own Hellenic identity.
Also, even though Orthodoxy has fused with the Hellenic civilization, the reverse is not true. Pre-Christian Hellenic society was open to new ideas, very philosophical, and ever-expanding. Ancient Greeks would have laughed at the idea that there should only be one true belief allowed (Orthodoxy = correct belief). Many different beliefs existed in ancient Greek. Philosophical schools worked constantly to come up with new theories and ideas, and they debated with other schools. This is why I say that "Hellenic Orthodoxy" is an oxymoron.

Westbury White Horse is the oldest of the Wiltshire horses. It is also one of the best situated, being high on a very steep slope and overlooking a panoramic view. It is on New Cumorah Hill (old Westbury Hill), on the edge of Bratton Downs, immediately below an Iron Age hillfort called Bratton Camp, northeast of Westbury, and near villages of Bratton and Edington. There is a car park with a viewing point on the B3098 just east of Westbury, and a car park above the horse on New Cumorah Hill. Lanes up onto the hill are steep and narrow, and are used by horse riders. There has been a white horse on the site for three-hundred (300) years at least. In 1742, the Rev. Wise published the earliest mention of New Cumorah Hill's white horse in "Further Observations on the White Horse and other Antiquities in Berkshire." Mr. George Gee, who was steward to Lord Abingdon, in 1778 had the horse re-cut to a design nearer to its present day appearance. He apparently felt that the older version was not a sufficiently good representation of a horse. One may wonder if the name 'Gee Gee' had made him overly sensitive about horses.

Angel Moroni, himself, buried them inside the *ORIGINAL* Eye of Westbury White Horse. They are embedded in pozzolanic (hydraulic) cement made from Stonehenge pulverized volcanic ash and tuff (containing silica and alumina) and ground lime mix sealing their Bluestone aggregate concrete encasement. A century later the horse had become misshapen, and in 1873 it was restored according to the Rev. Wise LDS Committee, and edging stones were added to help hold the chalk in place. The shape of the present horse dates from this restoration. In the early 20th century, additional concrete was added to hold the edging stones in place. In the late 1950s, it was decided that it would considerably reduce the maintenance costs if the horse were covered in concrete. This work was carried out, and concreting was repeated in 1995. At a later date, White Horse eye pavers, and concrete, were painted.

>Following the vir triumphalis and his chariot were the soldiers of the victorious army. In contrast with the general, they wore full military garb and regalia. They would shout “io triumpe”, a phrase of which the meaning was then and is now still not understood. >The laurel wreath was normally worn only on the day of the triumph, but when Caesar was appointed dictator in 44 BCE, he was wearing the wreath again.

>The Egyptian Empire had pretty much dwindled to an irrelevant power by the time the Old Testament would have been written, so there is little utility behind blaming Egypt for the woes of the Israelites--instead they could have blamed the Assyrian Empire which was a much greater threat around the time period, and a direct enemy of the Israelites considering they destroyed Israel and took many Israelis as slaves. >If God's knowledge can't be false then I can't possibly do anything that would prove god wrong.
Knowledge doesn't bind you.
>conditions are such that no other actions could possibly have been taken.
Yes it could. And God would know it if it were. Knowledge doesn't bind you.
>he already knows if I'm ultimately going to choose to follow him or not, I can't prove that knowledge wrong.
Knowledge doesn't bind you.

I feel like your key premise is that knowledge binds you. It doesn't. A thought experiment should clear this up:
1/ Imagine a truly free person, God is out of the picture, nobody knows anything
2/ The person chooses what color they like
3/ You rewind time by 5 seconds
4/ Same thing happens. The exact same thing....
5/ ... except to you the person becomes bound by your knowledge. Because you think knowledge is binding. Whereas in fact it doesn't affect the person in the slightest. They were as free before as they are now.

I admit it is very counter-intuitive to reconcile freedom with knowledge. But the premise of your problem doesn't hold water. Knowledge doesn't affect you.

>How is this supposed to convince me? God hasn't revealed anything to me and just taking other people's word for it isn't enough for me so what am I supposed to do?

Well, I think we're dealing with two separate issues here. The first issue, which I addressed in my post, is how free will can be consistent with an omniscient God.

But the more basic and fundamental issue, as you rightly note, is the existence of God, or not.

Now, people come to belief in God in different ways. Quite often, it is through an overwhelming perception that the orderliness and evident design of the universe, and of humans and animals, could hardly have come about by chance, or as the end result of a primeval explosion (explosions generally result in disorder, not order). For instance, a man named Whittaker Chambers, a convinced atheist who was once quite famous as a Soviet spy, found himself coming to belief through an epiphany he experienced while holding his infant daughter at night:
>My eye came to rest on the delicate convolutions of her ear -- those intricate, perfect ears. The thought passed through my mind: "No, those ears were not created by any chance coming together of atoms in nature... They could have been created only by immense design.

It is hard to address this sort of thing without having a conversation. But I can tell you what worked for me, and that is to pray. Pray to the God who may or may not exist. Ask for the gift of faith, of belief. Ask that you might see -- for that is what faith is analogous to.

In my own case, it took a few years for that prayer to be answered. But in retrospect, that time was like a very gradual dawning of light upon a darkened landscape -- what was impenetrable and indistinct became illumined, and I could see.

Trust that God is good.

Conversion stories can be helpful, as guides of a sort. Here is one, about how the actor Alec Guinness came to faith: https://desuarchive.org/his/thread/14432034/#14432797

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14491579
>Can you explain this? I'm not familiar with the term.
Modality is the philosophical term for possibility and necessity. So, an argument commits the modal fallacy when it involves an invalid inference about something's possibility or necessity. Such an argument might take the following form:
1. Necessarily, if P then Q.
2. P.
3. Necessarily, Q.
This is a fallacious argument. You are only allowed to conclude that Q is the case, but not that it's necessarily the case. Now, this exact fallacious argument form is instantiated by the standard argument that free will is incompatible with divine foreknowledge. That argument goes:
1. Necessarily, if God knows that you will do X, then you will do X.
2. God knows that you will do X.
3. Necessarily, you will do X.
This argument is invalid because it commits the fallacy shown above. You are only allowed to conclude that you will do X, but not that you will necessarily do X. So, this argument fails to show that divine foreknowledge is incompatible with free will in the sense of the ability to do otherwise.

I'm the anon who linked the Alec Guinness story. Like you, I was raised Catholic, then lost my faith. Like you, I never became a full-on atheist.

It's frustrating when it seems like God doesn't seem to answer or perhaps even hear our prayers. I am all too familiar with this experience. I know it provides but scant comfort, but I would encourage patience -- and indeed even to pray to God for the grace to be patient.

>I started critically examining the christian conception of God ... I haven't found that it hold up to scrutiny.

Eventually when, some years after my loss of faith, I again began to examine the Christian claim, I came across an argument that I found quite persuasive -- that is, the case for the Resurrection as based on the historical evidence.

This case is made out in two short books which, I think, complement each other. I highly recommend them both.

The better written of the two is Michael Green, Was Jesus Said He Was? It's out of print, but there are inexpensive used copies on Amazon and elsewhere.

The more detailed exposition of the evidence is made in Josh McDowell, More than a Carpenter.

Both books are quite good. Now, there are books that set out essentially the same argument in greater length and detail, if you were interested. The most notable of these, the big kahuna, is N.T. Wright, The Resurrection of the Son of God. An accessible and well-done video treatment is given in this series: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ErnJF_nwBk&list=PL1mr9ZTZb3TUYymBPce08oyuhnHLLkR_B, with episode #2 being the core and key episode.

I would also encourage you to read a couple of books of conversion stories, in particular, the aforementioned Surprised by Truth.

Also: Spiritual Journeys, edited by Robert Baram. Unfortunately out of print, but once again inexpensive used copies are available at Amazon* and elsewhere.

*https://www.amazon.com/Spiritual-Journeys-Robert-Baram/dp/0819868760/

Give Jesus another chance. Blessings, anon.

You have free will because He has given it to you. Period. And that gift is vouchsafed to you in the pages of sacred Scripture.

Believe in order that you might understand, as St. Augustine counseled. Words echoed by St. Anselm of Canterbury:

“For I do not seek to understand in order that I may believe, but I believe in order to understand. For this also I believe -- that unless I believe I shall not understand.”

Truly, humility is wanted here, anon. Humility and faith.

For although they knew God,
they did not honor Him as God
or give thanks,
but they became futile in their reasonings,
and their senseless hearts were darkened.
Romans 1:21

Be as the wise, not the unwise. The fear of the Lord -- that is, profound reverence before God -- is the beginning of wisdom (Prov 1:7).

Faith and reason work in a reciprocal manner. Believing in God, we see new vistas of truth. As we reason through these vistas, our belief in God is further confirmed. We believe in order to understand because, like Paul and Augustine, we know that without affirming the existence of God and His goodness, we cannot make ultimate sense of the world, or our place in it.

>Why'd Staling do all his old buddies so dirty during the great purge, was he really just power hungry?
On the contrary. Stalin's goal was to consolidate Soviet power for generations to come. He wasn't your typical Latin American presidente-por-vida whose system falls apart as soon as he's deposed in a coup. Stalin knew perfectly that the USSR was a one of a kind experiment, and that it would have countless enemies that would work 24/7 to put it down, consciously and unconsciously. For example, the existence of a powerful Red Army was a threat to Soviet power - if the Army grew stronger than the Party, the USSR would end up as a military dictatorship in the best case, and a fragmented warlord wasteland like Mexico and China in the worst case. So Stalin made sure that the Red Army would always be in an inferior position to the Party by shooting all relevant commanders. And about old Bolsheviks, Stalin knew them well, he was aware tha he dealt with idealists in some cases (Berziņs), personal ambition in other cases (Kamenev) and finally pure omnicidal schizos (Trotsky). Stalin needed internal and external stability for the USSR to thrive, maybe to even exist. And those people were obvious obstacles in the path of Realpolitik and Socialism in One Country. You may blame Stalin for being true to his conviction that there are several things which are more important than personal liberty and individual rights, but if you believe that personal liberty and individual rights are sacred, you have a petit bourgeois mindset anyway.

The attacking Germans were already far ahead of their planned places due to individual commands being so gung ho and experiencing early success.

Germany didn’t have precise details on the numbers or weaponry of the allies. Hitler certainly did not see Britain as a natural enemy. And wanted peace. He also saw the British empire as quite important to keep in place compared to most other powers who wanted to dismantle it. Even Britain’s allies like the USA or Soviets wanted it dismantled.

>>14498880
Incorrect. They were still courts martialed under the charge of violating Article 28, but then convicted of the lesser sentence. It's a not a cover up, its a plea bargain.
During the Seven Years War, they were 11 Article 28 courts martial, 4 of which were acquittals and 7 of which were convicted of lesser charges. The sea going population of the Royal Navy at the time was about 80000 men.
There's a few other incidents that didn't reach courts martial; NAM Rodger in the Wooden World reports a Captain Churchill who shot himself as a result of a complaint of one of his men and few other officers who either deserted or were permitted to be found not guilty and then resigned their commissions.

>>14500534

>When?

Definetly by 13,000 to 10,000 years ago, but "maybe" as far back as 20,000 to 30,000 years ago.

>Why?

It was closely tied with food production. The very earliest and simplest stone constructions were (and still are) just a small stone cairn covering a deposit of food like salted meat or nuts to keep the mice out of it. This could be above ground or below ground and so long as the food was entombed in rock it'd be relatively safe from vermin. Likewise, people wanting to protect and entomb human remains would do the same thing.
The second kind of primitive stone construction is the (for lack of a better term) Inuksuk. Another kind of cairn, the Inuksuk is a standing stone sculpture meant to act as a trail marker or to designate an area of significance. Something like this most likely naturally lead into the idea of putting up megaliths for spiritual, ritual, or *time-keeping purposes.

*That maybe sounds stupid out of context, but a lot of the oldest megalithic structures have formations or focal points that coincide with things like the equinox or whatever. Basically the sun hits it right at a certain time of year and so in that way people have 'proof' of the season.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14499966
Crusader leadership made a deal with Venice to finance the construction of a massive fleet that would aid the Crusaders - something the entire Venetian state dedicated itself to building. However, the Crusader leadership's estimate for how many men - men who the funds to pay the Venetians were to be extracted from - would be utilizing Venetian means for their passage to the Levant. Many Crusaders took alternative routes to the Levant and Venice seemed pose to take a massive financial loss in exchange for their investment. Eventually, after the Venetians and Crusaders cooperated to attack the city of Zara for Venice as a means of placating them, another financial opportunity seemed to rise in the form of the deposed Byzantine prince - the future Alexius IV Angelus - whose father had been the prior emperor only to be usurped and blinded by his brother. While Alexius also overstated the amount of support he could expect from the denizens of Constantinople, his uncle would eventually flee the city with a massive chunk of the treasury after facing the Venetian and Crusader army which lead to the restoration of Alexius' father (who was blinded) alongside the institution of himself as co-emperor. Alexius not only struggled to pay the Crusaders' back due to the state of the treasury compared to the scale of his promises - promises which included assistance on the actual Crusade - but he would also further rely on the Crusaders to solidify his powerbase which furthered the extent of his promises. At the same time, there were tensions between the Latins and Greeks while the Byzantine nobility was also unfavorable towards the Latins. Alexius IV would eventually have to take a tough stand against his former allies but would nevertheless be usurped by an anti-Latin official he freed earlier. The Latins would be evermore concerned about the fulfillment of Alexius' debt to them after Alexius, himself, was murdered by this usurper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14499999
The death of Alexius, leaving the Latins with nobody favorable to treat with, furthered the march towards the event known as the Sack of Constanpinople. The murder of Alexius, who was once very friendly with the Crusader leadership by this usurper, also further strained any hope at negotiation - not that this usurper Alexius V Doukas - would have embarked on paying off the Latins to begin with. As the conflict intensified, Alexius V would also flee from the city. The city elite seemed pose to offer the crown of Byzantium to the de jure leader of the Crusade, Boniface of Montferrat - whose family had ties to Byzantium, but Boniface's control over the Crusade was divided amongst a series of men/factions with different interests and so he couldn't stop the sack or even accept the crown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14500020
By the time the sack completed, the Crusaders now divided the territories of former Byzantium amongst themselves with Baldwin of Flanders being elected over Boniface by a council set up which was divided between Venetians and Crusaders. Their commitment to their new territories, which would soon by under threat by Byzantine successor states and Bulgaria, was once such factor preventing any further march towards Jerusalem. The sheer scale of riches plundered also proved satisfactory to many parties.

Ironically, much earlier in the Crusade - after the institution of Alexius IV as emperor - an exiled Seljuk prince in the capital requested the Crusaders also help him retake his state - offering rewards and promising to convert to Catholicism in exchange for such (it's worth noting the conversion of Byzantium to Catholicism was also a promise of Alexius IV - a promise that increased his personal difficulties in fulfilling his various promises). That Seljuk prince would be turned down, with the Crusaders not wanting to eternally restore wronged parties to their various thrones and Alexius IV's promises still being unfulfilled, but would eventually restore himself to the Seljuk throne without Crusader help. It would be interesting, in an alternate world, where the Crusaders did restore him and he converted to Catholicism. Supposedly, the institution of Catholicism in Seljuk territories wouldn't have been as impossible as one would first imagine (although, I imagine it still would be a fair challenge, to say the least) from what I've read.

posts.com: ...Nixon's first steady girlfriend was Ola Florence Welch, whom he met when they were Whittier Union High School classmates and dated on and off for six years. The relationship was not destined to be--both were too young and lacked the maturity to make it work. The two did not have mutually compatible politics--the Welches were staunch Democrats and FDR admirers, while Nixon hated the 33rd president. "He believed it wasn't the government's job to help you out in hard times. Well, I didn't agree on that and we had many lengthy arguments over it," Ola recalled. Her father, the chief of police of Whittier, thought the son of a grocer was too low on the totem pole for his daughter to marry. They began dating other people when they were supposed to be engaged. Ola's sister Dorothy, who was into fortune-telling, read her palm and predicted that marrying Richard Nixon would be a mistake and bring disaster to both parties. Their six year courtship ended painfully one day in 1935 when Nixon learned that Ola had another man over to her house--Gail Jobe, the son of a rancher and more acceptable to her snobby parents. They ended up getting married, and stayed married for almost 80 years--Gail passed away in 2014 at the age of 103, and Ola followed several months later, aged 102. One of Nixon's relatives speculated that the unfortunate end to his courtship of Ola instilled in him a lifelong distrust of people that marred his political career.

>>14498870
What are these "elephant funeral rites"? I always hear about "muh animals sometimes have religious behaviors too" but these behaviors always boil down to very simple habits, and there's no indication that any animal has an abstract affection for their dead.

If an animal feels sorrow over one of its pack dying, it's because the animal is upset it won't get to be around that friend anymore--but there is no consideration of real abstract empathy for their fallen friend. The feeling is always "this negatively effects me, and that makes me sad", and no "I wonder how this effects others in my pack, and how can I cope with this loss".

Other times, animals might bury their dead because leaving their dead in the open would attract predators, or have some other negative effect on the rest of the pack that needs to be addressed.

As for crows and other birds, this is what I've seen. Birds are taught to solve puzzles: such as, the coins go in the slot hole, the trash goes in the trash box, the rings go on the ring holder. But again, that's not abstract, that's all physical and memory based.

>Shallit (and Hume) are mistaken. Animals are incapable of abstract thought. Animals (and people) are capable of thought about particular things — objects in the real world. They are also capable of evaluating, comparing and distinguishing particular things, a capacity that scholastic philosophers called sensus communis. Sensus communis is the root of the modern term “common sense,” although as a term in philosophy of the mind it means the ability to evaluate particular things, without abstract thought.
>Abstract thought is the contemplation of universals, abstracted from particulars. Abstract thought is about concepts: mathematics, ethics, philosophy, logic, and the like. Abstract thought is about things that cannot be instantiated in particulars, although abstract concepts can be represented in particulars. For example, the concept of “justice” can be represented on a computer screen (I’ve just done it), but justice (as a concept) can’t actually be on a computer screen.
>Animals think about particulars, and only about particulars. They can’t think about universals. Contemplation of universals is an ability only of human beings, who have immaterial intellect and will, and are thus capable of contemplating immaterial concepts.
The problem with this discussion of "abstract thought" is that most of you are getting caught up in the "signs" and not the "concepts".
An ape could be given a list of words and symbols and told to match them up according to what it was taught by its human evaluators. It can match the "chain symbol" to the word "prisoner" and it could match the "smile symbol" to the word "happy" and so on, but there is no evidence to suggest that those animals actually understand the complexity of what it means to be a prisoner, or to be happy.

>1.4% gain for "conceivable but not possible"
>0.7% gain for "metaphysically possible"

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14499248
They were retards. Literally. They sent unfit highschool dropouts to bolster their manpower and only ended up hindering operations in the region. WWII vets did get PTSD but the worst of it was mitigated by a booming economy and a warm welcome back home. 'Nam vets had neither and so their fucked up psyche was much more immediately noticable to greater society.
>10 times as many died in WW2
Yes but the majority of casualties in the war were from bombing campaigns. It was a professional war between divided fronts and mass mobilisation from area to area. It allowed time for troops to rest and not be nervously overworked by the type of constant shelling we saw in WWI.

Vietnam was a theater of guerrilla warfare that the United States hadn't fought in over 60 years. Living veterans had little experience with jungle warfare. The front was a mess and constantly shifted as allies became turncoats and the enemy dug tunnels underneath your feet. WWII vets were conditioned to combat that involved overtaking entire towns in a relatively uniform manner. Vietnam vets had to watch for treelines, parked vehicles, civilian collaborators, and even fucking soda cans in the road became IED hazards.

Lastly, PTSD wasn't well understood or studied at the time. Medical experts understood the correlation between combat and the various nervous disorders they saw in WWI vets, but the field was still in its infancy. Some WWII vets probably did have PTSD. See: Patton slapping a soldier who had a nervous breakdown in combat.

I suppose it depends on what the process of creation is actually like. Is omnipotence the ability to do anything, or the ability to do anything any possible way? For example, if God is the external entity who produced logic, would he nonetheless accomplish his goals via logic?
If we can agree that logic is good because it provides reason, then we can agree that God must adhere to logical structures when creating the Universe.
It might be that genetic defects are a result of the overarching logic of creation, and the net good of that logic overcomes the evil of its consequences.
For example, if the good logic of god required that creation be very painful, and God was required(In order to uphold the good logic, but not because he is incapable of violating it), how much pain is God morally obligated to endure to be considered good by the standards of mortals? Could you even measure the amount of pain a God could suffer in the name of upholding the principles that underpin the cosmos?
Is God disqualified from omnipotence if a system of logic simply demands certain outcomes, and to defy them would be to destroy that system?

Evil is cancer that rots and distorts the soul. We all have equal potential to be cancerous, and we all have equal potential to be evil. But cancer does not always arise in some people--and sometimes it does, and it doesn't kill them, or they overcome it. So too does evil not always destroy the soul, and can sometimes be overcome by an individual. But, if it's true that evil and cancer do not always immediately arise during our birth--and will often hit us hardest when we get older and more experienced--then it follows that there should be a place to separate the evil from the non-evil.

If cancer were not just a disease that decomposed the body, and were instead a zombified parasite that caused individuals to become monsters and dangers to others, then we would also want to separate people into two categories: the first category, those who may still have the cancer in them; the second category, those who we know do not have the cancer in them.

Heaven was once a place we were created into, but there we retained our free will, and there some of us--like Lucifer--used our free will to do evil and attempt to overthrow God. Now, we are separated into two groups... on Earth, those people who still have evil inside of them, and Heaven, those people who have overcome the evil and no longer feel an urge to do it.

So Heaven is a place where we retain our free will, and is also without evil, but it is only so because the good and the evil are separated before going to Heaven.
